title: The Coming Judgment
shortSummary: Ezekiel Chapter 7 pronounces the imminent and unavoidable judgment of God upon the land of Israel due to their persistent sin and abominations. The chapter vividly describes the severity of God's wrath, the destruction that will come, and the certainty that His justice will be executed, serving as a solemn warning to repent and recognize the Lord's sovereignty.
timeline: c. 593 BC - Early Babylonian Exile period during Ezekiel's prophetic ministry

keyCharacters.name: Ezekiel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet receiving and delivering God's message of impending judgment to Israel.

keyCharacters.name: The people of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The recipients of God's judgment due to their persistent sin and rebellion.

keyCharacters.name: The king and princes
keyCharacters.description: Leaders of Israel who will experience mourning and desolation as part of the judgment.

definitions.definition: Detestable sins or practices that provoke God's righteous anger, often idolatry or moral corruption.
God's just and holy anger against sin and rebellion.
A coarse material worn as a sign of mourning, repentance, or distress.
A symbol of judgment and discipline, here representing the instrument of God's punishment.

outline.heading: Announcement of the End and Judgment
outline.description: God declares through Ezekiel that the end has come upon Israel, and His anger will be poured out to judge them according to their sinful ways and abominations.

outline.heading: The Day of Trouble and God's Fury
outline.description: The chapter emphasizes the certainty and imminence of the day of trouble, describing it as a time of God's fierce judgment with no escape.

outline.heading: The Inescapable Judgment and Its Effects
outline.description: The consequences of judgment are detailed, including violence, famine, pestilence, and the uselessness of wealth to save from God's wrath.

outline.heading: Defilement and Loss of Protection
outline.description: God's holy places and treasures will be defiled and given over to foreigners as a result of Israel's sins and rejection of God.

outline.heading: Final Judgment and Recognition of the LORD
outline.description: The chapter concludes with the inevitability of destruction, the collapse of leadership and counsel, and the ultimate recognition that the LORD is the righteous judge.

application: Recognize the seriousness of sin and the certainty of God's righteous judgment, leading to sincere repentance and obedience.
Do not place confidence in material wealth or human strength, but trust in God's mercy and seek His forgiveness.
Respond to warnings from God's Word with humility and readiness, avoiding complacency in spiritual matters.
Maintain faithfulness in prayer and worship, acknowledging God's sovereignty even in times of trial and judgment.

keyVerses.text: Also, thou son of man, thus saith the Lord GOD unto the land of Israel; An end, the end is come upon the four corners of the land.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the tone for the chapter, declaring the certainty and universality of God's impending judgment on Israel.

keyVerses.text: And mine eye shall not spare, neither will I have pity: I will recompense thee according to thy ways and thine abominations that are in the midst of thee; and ye shall know that I am the LORD that smiteth.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes God's justice and the personal accountability of Israel for their sins, highlighting the purpose of judgment to reveal God's identity.

keyVerses.text: They shall cast their silver in the streets, and their gold shall be removed: their silver and their gold shall not be able to deliver them in the day of the wrath of the LORD: they shall not satisfy their souls, neither fill their bowels: because it is the stumblingblock of their iniquity.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches that earthly riches cannot save from divine judgment and may even be a cause of stumbling if trusted above God.

keyVerses.text: The king shall mourn, and the prince shall be clothed with desolation, and the hands of the people of the land shall be troubled: I will do unto them after their way, and according to their deserts will I judge them; and they shall know that I am the LORD.
keyVerses.significance: It concludes the chapter with the assurance that God's judgment is just and purposeful, leading to the recognition of His sovereign authority.
